Accessibility.html:
Overview

Momentum has keyboard operation built into all of its components, improving the experience for visually impaired users and other users who operate using the keyboard. The Chip component has been designed to meet the accessibility guidelines.

Keyboard interactions (Input Chips)

Controls

OR

To move focus to next element.

Controls

Or

To remove a chip

All input chips will have delete icon. When focused on a chip, Delete or Backspace will delete the Chip.

Keyboard interactions (Filter Chips)

Controls

OR

To move focus to next element.

Controls

Or

Space / Enter will select and un-selected focused chip. Multiple selection is possible.

Screen Reader

When chips are implemented, the label likely will require additional context to be announced by the screen reader. Decide what should be announced for the following: name, role and value. Accessibility labels should include both the label and role. The accessibility label for a chip should comes from the visible label text on the chip. Align the accessibility label (used for assistive technology devices like screen readers) with the visible label text.

Spec.html:
Anatomy

Container: Chip containers hold all chip elements, and their width is determined by those elements. A container can also be defined by a stroke Label: Chip label can be an entity name, description, tag, action, or conversational. Close Button: Input chips can include a Close Button. Icon (optional): Icon can be used as a visual element to help indicate Chip’s purpose Avatar (optional): Avatar can be use to indicate that it’s a user

States

*Drag component is 50% opacity of Rest component

Tokens

Sizing

Default chip height is 24px height.

Spacing

Input chips

Icons and avatars should be 16px by 16px. The Chip container has 8px padding on the sides, and 4px spacing between the elements.

Filter chips

All the same spacing and padding rules from Input Chips apply to Filter chips, however, Filter chips do not have a close button.

Label chips

All the same spacing and padding rules from Input Chips apply to Filter chips, however, Filter chips do not have a close button.

Component spacing

Chips should have 16px padding between other surrounding components.

Color

Filter and label chips has a set of colors that can be applied to create visual differentiation from other elements on the page.

*Common Theme Tokens

Guideline.html:
Overview

Chips are used to show added items within a form, make selections, filter content, or trigger interaction. These items can be valid or invalid.

Usage

Chips allow users to enter information, make selections, filter content, or trigger actions. They typically reflect the input a user types in, but can also represent static information. Chips can be manipulated by editing the text or deleted by clicking on the x. While buttons are expected to appear consistently and with familiar calls to action, chips should appear dynamically as a group of multiple interactive elements.

When to use

Chips can show multiple interactive elements together in the same area, such as a list of selectable movie times, or a series of email contacts. There are four types of chips: filter, input, and label.

Anatomy

Container: Chip containers hold all chip elements, and their width is determined by those elements. A container can also be defined by a stroke Label: Chip label can be an entity name, description, tag, action, or conversational. Close Button: Input chips can include a Close Button. Icon (optional): Icon can be used as a visual element to help indicate Chip’s purpose Avatar (optional): Avatar can be use to indicate that it’s a user

Types

There are three different types of chips to accommodate various use cases.

1

2

3

Input Chips

Input chips represent information entered by a user, such as name, number, email address, etc. Avatar and icons are optional.

Filter Chips

Filter chips represent filters for a collection. Selected Filter Chips will have a checkmark icon.

Label Chips

Label chip is used to show any type of static status or presenting dynamically generated suggestions. Icons are optional.

Input Chips

Input Chip is able to take in inputs from the users.

Input chips should be paired with an text field to take in the user input. Input Chips can be dragged and re-ordered. Already inserted labels cannot be edited. To change the chip label, users must remove the incorrect chip and insert a new one. You can select/focus on the chip to copy the text content.

Filter & Label Chip

Filter & Label Chips usually will display the filtered results from the choices made by the user, or dynamically generated suggestions.

Users can interact with a filter chip by clicking. Once chosen, the chip will display a checkmark and Press/Active color background. Static suggestion chips carry no user interaction. Filter chips are always used in a group and not as single individual chip.

Dos and Dont’s

Chips should be simple and straight to the point. Minimize the word count, and any avatars, icons and checkmarks should be used appropriately.

Keep labels short. Add more details below or in a tooltip.

Label shouldn’t need to be over explained or expanded on. Use the full context of the component and UI to your advantage.

Content

Content

All chip label text is sentence case unless it is a proper name or otherwise requires a different casing. User input text should keep whatever formatting was entered.

Labels

All chip types must have a label. Label word count, including spaces, should be no more than 20 characters. For Input chips, the label content can be longer than 20 characters for things like email, name, location etc. Filter and Label chips should be simple one or two-word max.

Text overflow

When the chip text is too long (which should be rare) for the available space, truncate it. Use a tooltip on hover to show the full text.

Usable Example

Control Hub

Related Components

Button

If you need to show Call to Action interaction, use button instead.

Button

Text fields is one of the common component that is paired with Chips.
